title: Fresh Fava Beans, Roman Style
introduction: Fresh fava beans in their pods are a quintessential spring vegetable in central and southern Italy. Enjoyed for their tender texture and unique flavor, they are often eaten raw with young pecorino cheese or stewed with other seasonal vegetables like peas and artichokes. For the best experience, try them both peeled and unpeeled to see which method you prefer. Although fresh favas offer a different taste from their dried counterparts, frozen fava beans or lima beans can make a suitable substitute when fresh ones are not available.
ingredients: 4 pounds fresh fava beans, shelled (about 3 cups)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
instructions: In a medium skillet, cook the onion and pancetta in the olive oil over medium heat for 10 minutes or until golden.
Stir in the fava beans and salt and pepper to taste. Add the water and lower the heat. Cover the pan and cook 5 minutes or until the beans are almost tender.
Uncover the pan and cook until the beans and pancetta are lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Serve hot.
